ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught a lot about practical skills and concepts related to security.

This is a Security PRINCIPLES class, not a technical security class so much of what you learn is conceptual and is far removed from any application. I had to teach myself the majority of the technical content needed for the psets because the lecture content is very high level compared to the psets.
Learned about web & application security
to improve skills in computer security
Web security

I learned a lot of security concepts. I also learned how to work with other team members on a project. I also learned how to efficiently and concisely read and summarize research papers. Lastly, I learned how to prepare and concisely present a research paper.
Security foundations, including web security and software security.
Survey of computer security: how to model computer security; web security and how the internet works; application security

This class is an overview of system and web security. It covers well known attacks, exploits, and defenses. It is a valuable course for anybody interested in computer security, and fills a gap in Yale's computer science curriculum in a positive way.
security skill
I gained insights into computer security.
Little- I learned some very high level concepts about computer security and few technical details.
how to read and summarize CS research papers quickly; how to solve CTF challenges; web app security; all the things one might do with domains
I learned a ton about the way computers and the internet work and all of the different vulnerabilities and security concerns that come with that.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The time spent for each unit was very disproportionate.

The major strength of this course is that it teaches more practical knowledge about security, both through the lectures and the homework assignments. I feel like the course could be improved by giving students slightly more guidance when it comes to some of the homeworks because many of the concepts were totally unfamiliar.

The content was very interesting and the assignments (hacking challenges) were a fun new twist compared to other classes.
Pacing may have been slightly off but this was the first iteration of the class.
Going more in depth into technical concepts for each topic would have been extremely helpful. Lecture was not that engaging and the psets seemed very disjointed from the class content.

The content was really interesting, and I enjoyed what i was learning. I found it a little frustrating that the final project ended up not having much to do with what we learned in class, but that could be a side effect of it being the courses first iteration.
Final or Project

Strengths: Concepts are very relevant and useful in today's world. The material itself is very interesting.
Weaknesses: N/A

Strengths: covered a lot of topics (comprehensive) and a lot of practice

Weaknesses: lecture slides are not always straightforward to review

The course was well paced and there was a lot of content but it felt approachable. The OverTheWire challenges, where you "hack" a publicly available server or website, were fun and also taught me a lot in terms of "practical" security experience.

This is a very interesting course and it covers a lot of content. That's a big strength. Sometimes it was hard for the professor to cover all the material presented in one lecture. If anything, there was so much to learn, we didn't end up covering it all, or glossed over things quickly. All that said, it's a very good course. One of the only courses I've ever taken where I looked forward to doing the problem sets, they are very fun.
too much theoretical material and to less practice
The topics we learnt were very interesting and practical in the real world.

This course suffers immensely from fixation on irrelevant and tiny details, while not having the infrastructure to genuinely facilitate learning. One lecture, we spent 30-40 minutes talking about the different types of domain squatting, even though as soon as the slide listing an example for each was on the board, everyone knew exactly what each type referred to. Nearly all the psets are online challenges not curated for our class, so they feel wildly disjuncted with what we're learning and force students to basically look up guides because we didn't know php or sql. It takes a lot of work to create a class, but unfortunately in this case it is time to go back to the drawing board and rebuild with a focus on more technical learning and examples in class, and more curated psets that follow class material more closely.

Final Project was enjoyable and the options were fun to select from. Pretty low stress. The check-in meeting was helpful. 

Would have appreciated more canvas reminders about the quizzes. It's actually pretty costly to your grade to miss one or two. 

Final exam was substantially harder than the midterm.

Some lectures were a lot better than the others, like the domain security lectures were more engaging than the rest. It was a little too easy to zone out, most of the time.

The class was very well taught and the material was interesting, but the homeworks were sometimes difficult because you needed a much better understanding of the material than it was possible to get from just the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course.
Yes. Very interesting content about security, which is something that everyone should at least have passing knowledge of.

No, I would spend time taking other CS electives instead. This class isn't overly difficult, but there were many moments where I felt like I was learning nothing from the course that I couldn't have learned from a YouTube video going over high level concepts. My advice take a CS elective that actually improves your skills.
Yes, the course gives a great background in web security
Yes, the class was very interesting, helpful, and fun. If they ever want to work in the software engineering field, this would be a very useful class.

Yes, I would definitely recommend. Computer security is an important topic to be familiar with, especially if you go into software engineering or build your own projects, and this course provides a pretty comprehensive introduction to the topic. It would help to take the application security unit of this course after or at the same time as CS323 since it involves understanding assembly code.

Yes, I definitely recommend this course. The problem sets are extremely fun, and the content is very interesting. If anything, it should be split into two different courses to cover more material. Definitely take this course, I highly recommend it.
Yes
No the homework is unreasonably hard and not explained well in class. There were very few examples showing how to do the tasks in the homework
Yes.

Do not take this course. It is severely lacking in technical details and the psets are not aligned with in-class material very well. The quizzes and tests are also built on a lot of trivia-like knowledge from class as opposed to concepts, techniques, or explicitly taught technical skills. You really don't learn much in this class which is a shame because it could be fascinating.

Only if you have a prior interest in security or hope to focus on it for your career. I thought it might be cool to have some general "hacker" knowledge, but the material is at times too broad to feel useful or too specific to be interesting unless you're obsessed with the topic. Shop the class to get a feel for how engaged you are, the first week. It's a pretty good indicator of how the rest of the semester will go. It's easy to do well on homeworks and quizzes, if you don't miss them, but the final exam is hard. Not the easiest A.
Definitely. This was a very interesting class and not a huge work suck. If you are looking for an interesting CS elective to take, I would definitely recommend this.
